Award.AwardTitle: Indo-US Workshop on Multiscale, Multiphysics Analysis of Energy Conversion in Li-ion Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Indo-US Workshop on Multiscale, Multiphysics Analysis of Energy Conversion in Li-ion Batteries will be held on June 15-17, 2016 at the Indian Institute of Technology in Bombay, India. The workshop will bring together experts with diverse scientific and engineering backgrounds from the United States and India to discuss sustainable battery materials for electric transportation and renewable energy storage applications. The topics will focus on lithium ion and sodium ion battery materials with properties enabled through nanotechnology, and the development of advanced mathematical modeling tools to better understand the performance of these battery materials, particularly with regards to safe operation of lithium ion batteries. The workshop will support the travel of ten US-based university faculty members and graduate students to join a delegation supported by the Indo-US Science and Technology Forum.

The participants from the US and India will divide the workshop presentation topics equally to provide a comprehensive and interdisciplinary overview of lithium and sodium ion battery technology. The US participants will present topics on multifunctional materials, future battery chemistries, sustainable energy conversion, thermal transport, and thermal-electrochemical coupling. The participants from India will present topics on nanostructured material synthesis, Na-ion and Na-S batteries, multiphysics properties of nanostructures for energy storage, and molecular modeling. The participant interactions are expected to lead to US-India collaborations in nanostructured energy conversion materials, high-rate electrochemistry, measurement of thermal-electrochemical coupling parameters, and multiscale modeling of simulation of Li-ion cells, with particular focus on thermal-electrochemical processes underlying battery safety. Future collaborative research efforts will seek to establish multiscale structure-property-function relationships for lithium ion batteries, leading to models for electrochemical energy conversion need to develop safe and sustainable electric transportation systems. A workshop report will be published as an invited article to the ASME Journal of Electrochemical Energy Storage and Conversion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Intellectual Merit Outcomes of the Project

 

This project funded the Indo-US Workshop on Recent Advances in Multiscale, Multiphysics Analysis of Energy Conversion in Li-ion Batteries at the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay (IITB), Mumbai, India during June 17-19, 2016. In addition to funding from National Science Foundation, this workshop was also supported by a grant from the Indo-US Science and Technology Forum (IUSSTF). Funds provided by NSF were expended exclusively on US-based faculty and students.

This workshop resulted in technical discussions related to multidisciplinary analysis of electrochemical energy conversion and storage in Li-ion batteries. Experts from both US and India presented the state-of-the-art related to multiple technical aspects of the performance and safety of Li-ion cells. The disciplines represented in the workshop included mechanical engineers, chemical engineers, electrochemists, chemists and physicists. The workshop provided a common forum for deep technical discussions regarding the current state-of-the-art, future research needs, and priorities.

Following the workshop, multiple participants collaborated to summarize workshop discussions in an archival journal publication. This paper has been published with the following citation:

Shah, K., Balsara, N., Banerjee, S., Chintapalli, M., Cocco, A.P., Chiu, W.K.S., Lahiri, I., Martha, S., Mistry, A., Mukherjee, P., Ramadesigan, V., Sharma, C., Subramanian, V.R., Mitra, S., Jain, A., ‘State-of-the-art and future research needs for multiscale analysis of Li-ion cells,’ ASME J. Electrochem. Energy Storage Conversion, 14, pp. 020801:1-17, 2017. (DOI: 10.1115/1.4036456).

The publication presents key research needs in a number of technical directions relevant to electrochemical energy conversion and storage in Li-ion cells, and is a key outcome of the workshop.

 

2. Broader Impact Outcomes of the Project

 

This project resulted in professional development of multiple US-based students. The students were exposed to new research ideas relevant for their research. The international nature of the workshop also contributed towards their technical and professional development. For example, at least one Ph.D. student attending the workshop received an informal offer for a postdoctoral position from a participating faculty. Research based on the multidisciplinary ideas discussed at the workshop may lead to safer, higher-performance Li-ion cells that may impact a wide variety of applications in the future.
